attributes.comment:
To say the least, I am of the up most offended by such a proposed raise in rates.
I am the father of one son and one daughter who are adopted from a foreign
country. We are only now able to start the process for applying for the Certificate
of Citizenship for the one child, but need to wait until the courts finalize before we
can apply for the second CoC. While I make a good wage, such increases in fee
would require us make cuts in our budgets else where. I can only imagine what
would happen if a family that was adopting had less of an income as we do. We
are folks whom are trying to do the right thing in life and not only have a family, but
do so by helping a child of a foreign country. Our laws state that a child becomes
a US cititzen once the adoption to qualify parents becomes finalized. Why not
provide a Certificate of Citizenship automatically - at no cost. We are Land of the
Free and Home of the Brave....The Statue of Liberty doesn't say give me your
poor, your needy....for $600 dollars. Let's get real. We have set up the Dept. of
Homeland Security to have an integrated computer system with all the other US
federal agencies and dept., yet the Social Security Administration will not
recongize my son as a US Citizen until I produce a Certificate of Citizenship
(COC). How insulting.

Private NGOs and Non-profits must find ways to be more effecient at less cost,
but our federal gov't keeps increasing fees. How are families that are trying to
adopt supposed to keep putting up fees for USCIS paperwork, and still afford to
pay all the other cost that amount to and excess of $25,000. We can't keep
screwing the folks that want to do the right thing. My firm belief that the cost to
adopt should be a tax credit for the total cost of adoption, not just a set limit, and
not for a specific income bracket. Equal for all. Then at least I can get my money
back from the US Gov't that keeps taking money out of my wallet while kissing me
on my cheek. I have a cheek you can all kiss right here.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Christopher B. Owen
